text.title: part15_Augusten Burroughs on addiction, writing, his family and his new book
text.p: AB: Yeah. Not the thing to do.
AB: Get her drunk and get her tattooed.

p.hi: DS: [Laughs] I should--it would only take one drink with her.

text.p: AB: I think it'd be cool to have razor stubble tattooed here on my head, so that it'd look like I have really thick hair, but choose to have it very short.
text.head: On losing his hair

p.hi: DS: Was it difficult losing your hair?

text.p: AB: It was funny, because I've always been really good--I'm not--I'm not someone who goes into denial a whole lot. Even though I was a big lush, I knew it. I'm really honest with myself. And when my hair cutter told me, "Oh, you're losing your hair," I said, "Oh, no, I'm not. I've always had a high peak." Then I went home and looked at it, and I saw that I was really losing it. And I was horrified. It was my--it mattered too much. And so I deserved to lose it.
AB: It is hard. Women don't--it's like losing your breasts. Imagine if your breasts shrank up and shriveled away to cork nubs. I mean, it would really be--it's traumatic, it is.

p.hi: DS: I freaked out on my mom one time because she made a joke about it. I went overboard, I just freaked out. This was years ago, when it was just first starting to go a little bit. But I also always had a high peak, always.
DS: As a matter of fact, people made fun of me about it in my Georgia high school.

text.p: AB: That is something that people would make fun of you about in a Georgia high school.

p.hi: DS: Yeah. [In a southern accent] "Sportin' a pretty big forehead, there, Day-vid."
DS: I freaked out. "You don't know what it's like! You don't have any idea!” It was Christmas. But a person has to get to a point where he accepts it.
DS: Like when you see guys who try all these creative styles to--
DS: You know, pushing all their hair forward, when it's really--
DS: You know, and you think--

text.p: AB: You need to let it go.

p.hi: DS: Let it go. It makes it seem like they have trouble dealing with things.

text.p: AB: Hair becomes your psychological issue, you know?

p.hi: DS: Or reflection of psychological issues.

text.p: AB: Exactly. Yeah, exactly. It's the externalization of your denial. Better just to chop it off, although, you know, I have to say…
